sect1.title: Working with Message or Error-Logs
sect1.para: Message log files contain information about events that occur within a system. Their main scope is not performance, but rather health state of the system and possible problems. Message log records typically have a severity level such as ERROR, WARNING, or INFO. Message Log File evaluation can be initiated by
sect1.itemizedlist:
choosing appropriate log files in the Log File Selection Dialog (see ). Such log files typically contain one or more log lines per message.
choosing a log parser configuration with a Error Log File Parser Type.
pressing the Apply button.
sect1.para: &logtracker;'s can recognize "similar" messages and groups them automatically.
shows a sample of a message panel: Grouped messages are arranged in a table, one group per row. The table is sorted by the descending message severity. The columns show:

listitem.para: The severity of the messages of the group.
The date and time of the occurrence of the last message of the group.
The number of messages in this group.
The message content of the last message of the group.

sect1.para: Message groups that contain messages that occurred within the last ten minutes are colored: Recent errors have a red, recent warnings, a yellow and other recent messages have a green background.

The column with of the table can be adjusted with the mouse. Click and drag the right border of a column header cell for that purpose. Table columns can be sorted by left-clicking the column header cell.

When the user clicks within the row of the table, a log message detail window will pop up and show the individual members of a message group, i.e. all similar messages. A sample message detail window is shown in .
The message detail window consists of three parts:

listitem.para: shows the temporal distribution of the member messages of this group. Messages are automatically clustered based on their occurrence time and based on the scale of the plot. The position on the horizontal axis of the bars indicates the occurrence time, the height of the bars indicate the number of messages within a specific group. The zoom in can be done by selecting a rectangle with the mouse. A zoom out can be achieved by the use of the context menu, that can be brought up by right clicking in the plot.
shows the individual messages with their occurrence time, the calling user, the log source and the message content.

Select a single message within the message table and its full details are displayed in the message pane. The message pane is especially useful, when a message spans over multiple lines.
&logtracker; only keeps pointers to the messages in its memory. The full message content is only read from the log file when a user selects it. This behavior can lead to unexpected results, when a server uses log file rotation, since the message pointer in memory may point to a location that doesn't exist anymore or contains content that has no relation to the log line. Future versions of &logtracker; may include support for log-file rotation.
